page.title: 02CRAWLEY AN URBAN LIFE-CYCLE
page.content: {Ifield,}the oldest settlement, existed by 1086.{Crawley,}a newcomer, was a medieval hamlet on{Slaugham's}parish boundary. Growth modestly overtook Ifield as the embryo town emerged astride its transport routes. On {9.1.1947}Crawley and much of Ifield were incorporated in 6000 acres of a New Town. The master plan was by Anthony Minoprio, planning consultant for the Commission for the New Towns. The first young residents arrived by 1950, 75% from London. Gradually more balanced age structures emerged but Bewbush (76) is more youthful than West Green (49). From 1978 the Borough Council has owned housing assets but the Commission keeps commercial property which it develops, e.g. land near the station for parking, bus station and department store.{In 1985 {this is our 12th most prosperous town.
